instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3787A: What is 820-3787A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.PP_BUS: What is PP_BUS? This is a typo of PPBUS_G3H When you see PP_BUS, assume they meant to type PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .
definitions.820-3332A: What is 820-3332A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message:
Board is not powering ON, PPBUS, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> are present. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> are not present.

I have bypassed the SMC. I could see the fan running at high speed for few seconds and repeating. And the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>  is also present. Can I know how can I proceed?

Br
Manu

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message:
Sorry I was using a MagSafe charger with a variable power supply for measuring the current. That's the reason I didn't get  <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> .

Now I have connected an 85W charger directly, I can see the Fan is running for 5second, then stops and repeat the same. 
PPBUS - 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5.078V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - 5.034V


<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.349V-fluctuating along with Fan
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> is stable -3.349V

Br
Manu

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message:
Any history fault?

Try to start with both charger and battery connected.
Does it charge the battery at least?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message: When I connect battery and charger I can see a current consumption of 2.5 amp min , Seems like the battery is charging. Because I can see the green and yellow light on the charger.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message:
That is not a confirmation.
Check <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage; should increase slowly, when charges battery.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message: Ohh my lord, I don't know what happened suddenly. I don't have a <SIGNAL>PP_BUS</SIGNAL> anymore. Mag safe light is not glowing. <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> vdd (<SIGNAL>PP5V1_CHGR_VDD</SIGNAL>) is present. I/P also present (<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> - 19.7V). <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 0V. No idea why. Have I spoiled it :cry:??

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message:
Post basic <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> voltages; pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.
Use the pins of surrounding components as test points.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message:
Hi Kevin, 
Here is the voltages measured on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> 
pin 1 = 0V
Pin 2 = -20V
Pin3 = 4.768V
Pin9 = 0.059V
Pin12 = 0.096V
Pin13 = 0.080V
Pin14 = I couldnt measure
Pin15 = 0.0V
Pin17 = 0.255V
Pin19 = 5.475V
Pin20 = 5.479V
Pin27 = 19.76V
Br
Manu

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message:
"Pin12 = 0.096V"
Missing <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, board can't start.
Check for short at L7095 and post <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> voltages.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> - 
pin4 - 6.7V
pin 1 - 20.21V
pin 5 - 20.21V


<CHIP>U7090</CHIP>-
pin 6 - 18.47V
pin 3 - 1.063V
pin 1 - 0.589V
pin 4 - .256V
pin 2 - 0.096V

Shall I replace LT3470AED ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message:
Do you get voltage at pin 8 too?
Post diode mode to ground at L7095.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message:
Additional info:-
I have removed <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> and L7095. Still, there is a short (0.2Ohm) between the 2nd pin of the L7095 and GND.
In the diode - the voltage is 0V (After removing the inductor and <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message: I couldn't measure voltage at pin 8, Because  I have already removed the IC.Its clear that  <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> is not creating the short ,Still not sure what is causing the short at  <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message:
Use voltage injection method.
Start with 1V, no more than 4V.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message: What is the max current setting? I have a variable power supply with maximum 5Amp . I hope it can do the job. Additional to that I don't have a thermal camera. ☹️

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message:
"What is the max current setting?"
The MAX of your PSU; we discussed so many times on the forum about that.
The current is auto adjusted, depending by injected voltage and short resistance.
Please, try to understand Ohm law!

BTW, 5A doesn't help for short check many times.
If the short sinks more than 5A (sometime occurs even with 1V), PSU will get blocked.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message:
It is SMC , 
SMC is getting heating up in 1.4Amp itself.
I can remove an SMC from a faulty board and replace. Is there any tutorial for reballing ? Is it mandatory to have a stencil?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message:
You can place the balls by hand; tedious job however.
The stencil with solder paste is the fastest way.

threads.message: I have never tried this , should I buy balls separate? Do we have any guidance which I can follow?

threads.message: Several videos available on YouTube...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message: Is there an option I can buy a new programmed SMC? So that I can directly solder that instead of reballing

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>  23mA current consumption
threads.message: You need SMC from same model board, not new.

threads.message: One more question, Is smc program of <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> is compatible with <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>?
